articles.author: Sharon
articles.description:
If you're using SafeLine WAF or any reverse proxy with SSL enabled, you might encounter a confusing situation: 
When accessing your site via IP address instead of domain name, it returns a completely different certificate — often the default one.
Let’s break down why this happens, and why it’s not a bug but a behavior defined by the TLS standard.
Imagine this setup:
You configure a SafeLine site using your domain example.com.
SSL is enabled, and a proper certificate is applied.
You access https://example.com — everything looks perfect.
But then you try https://192.0.2.1 — and boom, you get a certificate mismatch or the default SafeLine certificate.
Before HTTP


Here's the key insight:
TLS handshake happens before the server ever sees your HTTP request.

That means the server doesn’t know …
articles.title: Why Does My SSL Site Return the Wrong Certificate When Accessed via IP?

articles.author: Thea
articles.description:
I just completed the latest Developer Nation Global Survey, and it got me thinking about how much our industry has evolved this year. If you're curious about where development is heading and don't mind the chance to win some solid gear, it's worth your time.
This isn't your typical quick survey. SlashData's Developer Nation survey has been tracking global development trends for years, and this edition dives deep into what matters to us as developers:
Programming languages and their real-world adoption
Frameworks & libraries that are gaining traction
Cloud platforms and infrastructure choices
DevOps & CI/CD practices that teams are implementing
AI tools and how they're changing our workflows
Beyond the solid prizes (we're talking $300 toward any AI tool, Logitech MX Master 3S, RODE NT-USB Mini, and various gift cards), there are genuine reasons to participate:
Community Insights: When the results drop, you'll get data-backed answers to questions like "What languages are growing?" and "How are teams using AI tools?"
Industry Impact: Your input helps shape the tools and platforms we all use. Companies pay attention to this data when making product decisions.
Good Cause: They've also added a donation component where your participation can contribute to charitable causes.
The survey runs until July 17, 2025, so there's still time to add your voice to the mix.
If you're interested in seeing where our industry is headed (and maybe winning something useful in the process), take the Developer Nation Survey here.
articles.title: What's Really Happening in Dev Right Now? (Plus a Chance to Win Some Gear)

articles.author: LBM Solution
articles.description:
The gaming industry has witnessed rapid changes over the past few years. The introduction of blockchain technology is one of the most impactful developments. From empowering players with ownership to creating new revenue models, blockchain is reshaping how we play and create games. In this blog, we will explore how blockchain in gaming is revolutionizing the industry, making it more secure, transparent, and player-friendly.
What is Blockchain in Gaming?


Before diving into the revolution blockchain has brought to gaming, let's answer a basic question: What is blockchain in gaming?
Blockchain is a decentralized digital ledger that records transactions across many computers. This means that data on a blockchain is secure, transparent, and cannot be changed without consensus from everyone in…
articles.title: How Blockchain Revolutionized the Gaming Industry

articles.author: Maggy Renoux
articles.description:
We’ve been running dashboards on AWS — mainly using Redshift with Power BI — and honestly, it's been rough. We’re dealing with slow load times, random breakages, and costs that are way higher than expected.
We’ve tried optimizing queries and resizing clusters, but it’s still messy. Is this just an AWS architecture issue, or are we doing something wrong?
Curious if others have moved away from AWS for dashboards or found a smarter way to handle this. Definitely open to hearing how others have solved it.
articles.title: Why do AWS dashboards keep breaking — and is there a better way?

articles.author: Swarup Mahato
articles.description:
JavaScript, being a single-threaded language, can only process one task at a time. This can result in long wait times for complex tasks, as the script will be blocked from executing any other tasks until it has been completed. To tackle this, JavaScript offers asynchronous programming, which allows the script to continue executing other tasks while it waits for an asynchronous task to complete. In this blog, we’ll explore the basics of asynchronous programming in JavaScript and how it can be achieved through the use of callback functions, promises, and async/await.
A callback function is a function that is passed as an argument to another function and is executed after the main function has been completed. Callbacks are used in asynchronous programming to wait for a task to complete before…
articles.title: Asynchronous programming in Javascript

articles.author: Sharon
articles.description:
If you're working with modern web infrastructure, chances are you've heard of both reverse proxies and Web Application Firewalls (WAFs). They’re often used together, and sometimes even confused with one another — especially when tools like SafeLine can act as both.
So... what's the actual difference?
Let’s break it down in dev-friendly terms.
A reverse proxy is like a smart middleman that sits in front of your web server. Instead of clients connecting directly to your app server, they connect to the reverse proxy, which then forwards the request internally.
Main jobs of a reverse proxy:
Load balancing
SSL termination
Caching
Hiding internal architecture (IP, ports, etc.)
Compression and traffic optimization
Popular examples: Nginx, HAProxy, Traefik
A WAF protects your web app by inspecting…
articles.title: Reverse Proxy vs WAF: What's the Real Difference?

articles.author: Bala Madhusoodhanan
articles.description:
Intro:
Documents may overlap in content, especially when policies vary by region or department. For example, a travel expense policy might have different rules for employees in the UK versus those in the US, all stored in separate but similarly titled documents. I found myself wondering: How exactly did the copilot decide which document to use when answering my question? Copilot Studio’s powerful preview features—reasoning models—which offer a behind-the-scenes look at how Gen AI orchestration interprets and generates responses.
Setup:
To simulate a real-world enterprise scenario, I built a Copilot Studio chatbot designed to help employees navigate internal policy documents—such as travel expenses, holiday entitlements, and other HR guidelines—stored in a SharePoint knowledge base.


The i…
articles.title: Decoding the Answer: How Copilot Studio’s Gen AI Orchestration Handles Complex Policy Queries
